text: - [Alaa] Hello and welcome
to the Amazon Sample Email Service
Deliverability Learning Series.
My name is Alaa.

I'm a senior cloud
support engineer at AWS.
I help the customers to understand
the email deliverability best practices

with a primary focus on
inbox deliverability.

Amazon SES is a cloud
email service provider
that can integrate into any application
for bulk email sending.
Senders from small startups
to large enterprise accounts can use SES
to reach their customers,

but getting messages to
the recipient's inbox
over the long term can be tricky.
Understanding deliverability best practice

and what mailbox provider
expect from bulk sender is a key
to getting messages to a customer's inbox.
Today we are going to be talking

about monitoring the
feedback available to senders

and how to interpret and
take action on that feedback
with the purpose of increasing

or maintaining your
positive email reputation.

In this video, we will
discuss the various ways
of monitoring your email feedback.
This includes an overview
on feedback loops and complaint data,

mailbox provider postmaster
tools and dashboards,
and email event monitoring.

Email event monitoring consists
of tracking deliverability
and engagement events like opens, clicks,
bounces, complaints, and unsubscribes.
The ability to identify

and analyze key performance
indicators that can be used

in evaluating how you
are doing as a sender

across many mailbox
providers will help keep

your messages following
to recipients' inboxes.

Sender reputation is the
profile mailbox providers build

specific to a sender with an
emphasize on domain reputation

but can also include an
impact IP reputation.

Sender reputation will
be heavily influenced
by how a sender monitors and responds
to the email feedbacks they receive
from mailbox providers and recipients.

Now let's deep dive into
monitoring complaint
and unsubscribe data.
Monitoring feedback can take many forms

when it comes to a
company's email program,

and it's important to review
them for both positive
and negative trends.
Looking at direct feedback like complaints

and unsubscribes can help
identify specific campaigns

or campaign series that can
be too aggressive in reach,
too frequent in cadence,

or possibly irrelevant
to the end recipient.

Identifying where the
recipient feedback originated

is important to help reduce
future spam complaints.

Feedback may come from
having messages marked
as a spam within a mailbox provider

who then relays that
information back to the sender
if a feedback loop exists.

There is also feedback in the
form of direct complaints sent
to an email abuse address listed

in the Whois information
for the sending domain.
Understanding the source

and reasons a complaint may
have been generated is the key
to reducing overall complaint rates.

Having a recipient
unsubscribe from an email,

even they are unsubscribing
from all communications,

is better than having a
user click the Spam button.

Unsubscribes can be a signal
of trust from the recipient

in that they trust that the
sender is who they say they are,
but the recipient may be uninterested

in the content or topic
being sent to them.

Only send recipients
what they want to receive
and what they opted into receiving.

This will promote the ability
to regularly communicate

with your recipients through
your company's email program
for long-term customer retention.

An important aspect of
monitoring feedback also resides

in list building and long-term
list hygiene strategies.
The list you use to send your messages

and where those recipients
originated are critical
to successful long-term inbox delivery.
Having opt-in records

and catering to your
recipient's preferences
can help you build out your email program,

but there is also a list
hygiene consideration

that have to be made when
evaluating the lists you build
and sent to regularly.

If recipients are not
engaging with the message,

typically identified
through opens, clicks,

site visit data, application,
login, or other methods

of tracking recipient
behavior and interest,

inactivity could be a
signal that the recipient

is no longer interested
in receiving your emails.

It typically means that
you should not keep them

on the active mailing list
or part of a specific topics
within a preference center,

requiring you to reduce
sends to that recipient.
Enabling feedback.

The most common mechanism
for complaint feedback
is the standard feedback loops or FPLs
as defined in the RFC 6449.
FPLs are the mechanism

in which mailbox providers
send complaint data
to the sender directly with information

that could help the
sender identify recipients
who marked the message as spam.

Spam complaint rates are often
associated with these FPLs

and represent a spam percentage
or rate from a sender
to the recipient mailbox provider.
Often there is a set threshold

at which point message
delivery is at risk,
and that rate is generally 0.3%
or higher for a spam complaints
to that recipient mailbox provider.
Many of the large mailbox such as Hotmail

and Yahoo have their own
FPLs and feedback mechanism.

Gmail does not send
all complaint feedback,
but they do expose complaint data as part

of their Google Postmaster
Tools dashboard.

We will discuss the
various postmaster tools

and sites related to the
largest global mailbox providers
later in this video.

In addition to individual
mailbox provider feedback loops,

there are also universal
feedback loops available
by third-party vendors that cover many
of the largest mailbox provider globally.
There are also many mailbox providers
that do not have standard feedback loops,

so understanding how to
deal with direct feedback
will still be important for senders.
Direct feedback is something
that all senders should consider.
Having an abuse and post master addresses
for spam complaint feedback

or another publicly available
abuse handling address
is a requirement you need to consider
when set up your sending domain.

It's better to get the direct
feedback from the recipient

and take care of the
complaint directly then

for the recipient to escalate
it to a network abuse contact
or mailbox provider abuse contact,

as those can result in enforcement
beyond just your domain

and could include network
provider level enforcement.
Complaints are one of, if not the most,
important factor when mailbox providers
are considering accepting your messages
and where to route them in terms of tabs:
inbox or spam section.

High levels of complaints
are an indicators
that the mailbox provider recipients
do not want the message you are sending,

and the mailbox providers
will treat sending domains

and IPs harshly if they see
higher issues of complaints.

This is why monitoring for
complaints is so important,

because you want to not
only remove the recipient
who marked the message as a spam
but also understand the reasoning.

For example, let's say a
company were to use a list
that was purchased or otherwise acquired,
and it resulted in a spike in complaints
and unsubscribes for that email campaign.
That increase in complaints
and unsubscribes should tell the sender
it's not a good idea to purchase lists

and doing so can negatively
impact your email program,
both short and long term.
The goal is to identify who is complaining
and why they are complaining.

Understanding these data
points will help you figure out

how you can reduce
complaints on your campaigns

in the future as you create
a long-term relationship
with your recipients.

Taking feedback data and
applying industry best practices
for complaints handling will help keep

your email program
healthy from complaints,
which will improve overall deliverability.

Understanding what your
audience wants to receive

and what they don't want is
also a key to a long-term sender

and recipient relationship
and should be the goal
of any large volume sender.
Monitoring engagement data.

While email complaints
can be the primary reason

for deliverability and
sender reputation problems,

user engagement like opens
and clicks can quickly improve
and reinforce positive sender reputation.
Positive user engagement like opens

and clicks indicate to
the mailbox provider

that the recipients on your
mailing list are interested
in what you are sending them.

The higher the overall user
engagement rate is for a sender,

the more trust a mailbox
provider is going to have

when they consider the sender
domain or IP reputation.
That sender reputation will dictate

how messages are routed
to the inbox, spam folder,
additional tabs, or possibly not at all
if the messages start to get locked.

The ideal open engagement
rate changes depending
on what industry you are in,

but a typically starting
point is about 20%
for marketing messages.

Factors like complaints,
unsubscribes, or even a high rate

of non-engaged recipients
do impact deliverability

and can cause message delays,
placement to the spam folder,
or even possibly getting blocked.
There can be some trade off
when it comes to engagement stats.

For example, if you are
seeing lower complaints

but are also seeing
lower opens and clicks,

your messages may be getting
routed to the spam folder,

so a decrease in a
negative engagement metric
like complaints is misleading,

which is why you do need
to consider all metrics.
You will also have cases

where you have a higher
than ideal complaint,

keeping in mind the ideal
complaint rate is 0.1% or less
but still delivered to the inbox.

For example, your complaint
rate might be closer to 0.3%,

but if you have a much
higher opens rate, like 40%,
that higher complaint rate is diluted
with a much higher opens rate.
As a result of the higher opens rate,

a majority of your messages
go directly to the inputs,

which will give more opportunities
for recipients to engage,

which may lead to the slight
increase in complaints.
You still do want to reduce the complaints
because the issue does matter,

but higher positive
engagement does indicate

that many of your recipients
do want your email.

How recipient engage with
messages from senders

is a big driver of how mailbox
providers route messages.
Monitoring bounce data.
SMTP response data is critically valuable
in email deliverability analysis.

Oftentimes when messages
are being bounced,

the response message from
the recipient mail server

may include an SMTP message
with a code indicating the type
of bounce, permanent versus transit,
and often it will have information related
to the reason of that bounce.

Most of times, the
message will also include
how to mitigate the bounce issue

or indicate what the
bounce actually means.

Here is a sample bounce
message from Gmail.

You can see in the SMTP response
message here, in this case,

it's a 4-2-1, which means
it's a transit error
and you can retry your message.

If you look into the
SMTP response body here,

it also indicates the
reason for the bounce
and then goes a step further by linking
to how to solve the issue.
In this example, Gmail is saying
that they are throttling the messages

because there is an an
alignment issue with either SPF
and/or DKIM related to the DMARC policy

for the domain in the from
header for the sender.

Understanding whether your
messages are being bounced

for an infrastructure
reason, configuration,
or larger, more holistic aspects
of your email program is so important.

That information will allow
you to focus your efforts

on the right approach to
resolve the issue long term.

For example, the bounce
message we just looked at

could be fixed with an
adjustment to DNS records.
This will be much quicker fix

than if you have a
larger problem with spam,

lack of user engagement.
or content issues.
Another example would be

that you have individual
mailbox provider issues specific
to what you send to that mailbox provider.
For example, you may have an issue
with Hotmail deliverability but not Gmail,

and you want to focus on the
Hotmail issue specifically

and align with Hotmail
sender best practices.
Monitoring bounce data can also alert you
of the start of problems before they grow

into large scale issues that
can be difficult to get out of

once negative sender reputation
has been established.
If you deal with throttling
and transient errors as they start,

you may resolve the
issue before they spiral
into a much longer lasting
and impactful deliverability problems.

If you allows those to go
unchecked and unresolved,

you may end up with a much
larger deliverability issue,

including outright
blocking of your traffic
by specific mailbox providers.

What's the master tools
and reputation data?
Email sender reputation is compromised
primarily of domain and IP reputation.
As the industry continues to shift
to an emphasize on domain reputation,

you will need to utilize
dashboards and tools available
that can represent this reputation states
at post IP and domain levels.
Many mailbox providers offer their own set
of dashboard and postmaster tools.
Three great examples of this are
Google Postmaster Tools, GPT;
Yahoo Sender Hub, YSH;

and Hotmail's Smart Network
Data Services, SNDS.
When reviewing this dashboard information,
you can approach it in multiple ways.

If you just want information
on how you are doing
with these particular mailbox providers,
the information available in most

of these dashboards will
give you an indication
on how you are doing placement wise

and engagement wise towards
those mailbox providers.

If you are trying to figure out
when your reputation dropped
or what led to deliverability issue,
you can look back at the data
and look for trend data on specific days.
The goal is to identify the campaign lists

or strategies that may
have changed or been added

during that time that may
have led to a degradation
in sender reputation or delivery results.
Often a shift in policy

or approach is what leads to
deliverability challenges.
Correlating those policies along

with enforcing email best
practices as you see them develop
will help you keep your program out

of negative email
deliverability challenges.
In addition to mailbox provider tools,

if you work with an
email service provider,

there are some tools
always in the application

that you can utilize to help
attract deliverability trends,

even specific to individual
mailbox providers
like Gmail, Yahoo, and Hotmail.

With Amazon SES, you have
the ability to choose

between several ways
to build the dashboards

and ingest your email event
traffic and bounce data.
I have included links to those resources
in the summary below this video.
SES does offer an out-of-the-box solution

called Virtual
Deliverability Manager, VDM,
which can help with data surfing

and bounce analysis
specific to the ISP level
and can be filtered in many ways,
like at the configuration set level
and domain identity level.

With VDM, you can see trends
over timelines in a dashboard,
which can help you catch bad trends early

before they turn into lingering
deliverability problems.
Another benefit of VDM is that it looks

at your verified sending
identities to ensure

proper DNS records are
associated with your domains.

So if you are missing an
authentication protocol

for your domain, VDM
advisor will alert you

of the missing DNS record
so you are not finding out

after a send and as a
result of failed messages.

For more on the SES Virtual
Deliverability Manager feature,

please review the links
provided in the summary.
Whether it's marketing, transactional,
or other bulk email communications,

deliverability tooling
provides valuable insights
into understanding how you are performing
across multiple mailbox box providers,

which is a primary
contributor to a healthy
and long-term email program.

In conclusion, monitoring
email deliverability
as a whole is important to maintain
a healthy email program for any company.

Understanding factors
like user engagement data
and how the impact your sender reputation

across many mailbox
providers is a critical.

With this information, you will
be able to better understand
what your recipients want to receive

and how to best get those
communication to them,

catching problems early on
and limiting negative trends,

like a rise in complaint
rate across a campaign

or campaign series, contributes
to a healthy sender profile.

When you have a positive
sender reputation,
and you are getting high inbox placement,
you can focus on the factors

that differentiate your
businesses to your customers

and not to have to worry as
much about email deliverability.

Utilize the tools within
your own application,

whether that's in-house or
with an email service provider,

to monitor deliverability
trends and performance.

When available, set up
dashboards on postmaster pages

to track your reputation with
the largest mailbox providers.

At times, you may need
to dig a bit further
into the bounce data to figure out

what the issue may be
and how to resolve it.
Having an application feature like VDM
and SES can help track trends
and service deliverability data,

including individual
message delivery results.

When considering how you
monitor your email feedback,

you are not only looking at
these factors for problems
but also opportunities.
There may be times when you establish
a great sender reputation,

and you may want to follow
that process as a template

across many of your campaigns
and sending domains.

Once you have established
good sender reputation,
it's still important to monitor

to ensure you are staying
flat or even trending up.
